newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bob Dylan saves face in German piracy case.
newsitem.headline: Bob Dylan saves face in German piracy case.

text.p: American folksinger Bob Dylan's face is now safe in Germany.
A German court on Tuesday ordered a compact disk manufacturer to stop marketing a bootleg recording of a Dylan concert that sported his face on the cover.
A legal loophole prevented the court from banning the pirate recording itself, but the manufacturer was forbidden from using the singer's image any longer.
The recording, made illicitly at a U.S. concert, went on sale in 1992, priced at nine to 15 marks.
Lower German courts had earlier ruled in favour of the defendant, Perfect Beat Tontraeger, because Dylan was deemed a person of historic importance.
Moreover, international regulations in effect since January 1995 allow the marketing of live recordings made outside the country.
The ruling has little practical consequence, because the manufacturer has gone into liquidation.
